When you run this code, you'll be given a warning that a key should be provided for list items. A "key" is a special string attribute you need to include when creating lists of elements. We'll discuss why it's important in the next section.
and fix the missing key issue.
Keys help React identify which items have changed, are added, or are removed. Keys should be given to the elements inside the array to give the elements a stable identity:
The best way to pick a key is to use a string that uniquely identifies a list item among its siblings. Most often you would use IDs from your data as keys:
When you don't have stable IDs for rendered items, you may use the item index as a key as a last resort:
We don't recommend using indexes for keys if the order of items may change. This can negatively impact performance and may cause issues with component state. Check out Robin Pokorny's article for an
in-depth explanation on the negative impacts of using an index as a key
. If you choose not to assign an explicit key to list items then React will default to using indexes as keys.
in-depth explanation about why keys are necessary
if you're interested in learning more.
Keys only make sense in the context of the surrounding array.
component, you should keep the key on the
elements in the array rather than on the
A good rule of thumb is that elements inside the
Keys Must Only Be Unique Among Siblings
Keys used within arrays should be unique among their siblings. However, they don't need to be globally unique. We can use the same keys when we produce two different arrays:
Keys serve as a hint to React but they don't get passed to your components. If you need the same value in your component, pass it explicitly as a prop with a different name:

So many times I have seen developers use the
It looks elegant and it does get rid of the warning (which was the ‘real' issue, right?). What is the danger here?
It may break your application and display wrong data!
is the only thing React uses to identify DOM elements. What happens if you push an item to the list or remove something in the middle? If the
is same as before React assumes that the DOM element represents the same component as before. But that is no longer true.

It turns out, when nothing is passed React uses the

because it is the best guess at the moment. Moreover, it will warn you that it is suboptimal (it says that in a bit confusing words, yes). If you provide it by yourself React just thinks that you know what you are doing which — remember the example — can lead to unpredictable results.

A production solution should use a more robust approach that would handle a distributed creation of items. For such, I recommend

Many people asked if they always,
have to generate ids. Others have suggested use cases when using the index as a key seems justifiable.
It is true that sometimes generating new ids is redundant and may be avoided. For example translation of license terms or list of contributors.
To help you decide, I put together three conditions which these examples have in common:
the list and items are static-they are not computed and do not change;
the items in the list have no ids;
may safely use the index as a key
Although in this article I write about React, the problem is not exclusive to it. In similar libraries, like Preact, the danger is present, too. However, the effects can be different.
